message_1: What is the rate constant of a first-order reaction that has a half-life of 10 seconds and an initial concentration of 0.1 M?
message_2:
The rate constant (k) of a first-order reaction can be calculated using the half-life (t1/2) with the following equation:

k = ln(2) / t1/2

Given that the half-life (t1/2) is 10 seconds, we can calculate the rate constant (k) as follows:

k = ln(2) / 10

k ≈ 0.0693 s⁻¹

The rate constant of the first-order reaction is approximately 0.0693 s⁻¹. Note that the initial concentration is not needed to calculate the rate constant for a first-order reaction.
